member.name: T:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.BufferAnalyst
member.summary: The BufferAnalyst class is used to create buffers for the point/line/polygon dataset (or recordset) and network dataset, which include single buffer, multi buffer, and one-side multi buffer for a line.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.BufferAnalyst.CreateBuffer(SuperMap.Data.DatasetVector,SuperMap.Data.DatasetVector,SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.BufferAnalystParameter,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates the buffer for the vector dataset.
member.param: The specified source vector dataset for creating buffer zones. It supports the point dataset, line dataset, polygon dataset and network dataset. The buffer analyst of the network dataset focuses on edges.
The vector dataset to store the result of the buffer analysis. It must be the region dataset.
The specified BufferAnalystParameter object.

Whether to merge all buffers, i.e., whether to perform a union operation on the buffers of the objects in the source data and return the result. For region objects, it is required that the objects in the source data do not intersect with each other.

Specifies whether to reserve the fields of the objects in the source dataset. However, For the region dataset, if union the objects and the buffer zone, this parameter is invalid, namely the isUnion is set to true.
member.returns: True if it is removed successfully; false otherwise.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.BufferAnalyst.CreateBuffer(SuperMap.Data.Recordset,SuperMap.Data.DatasetVector,SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.BufferAnalystParameter,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates the buffer according to the given vector recordset.
member.param: The specified vector recordset that creates buffer area. It supports point, line and region recordset.
The vector dataset to store the result of the buffer analysis. It must be the region dataset.
The specified BufferAnalystParameter object.

Whether to merge all buffers, i.e., whether to perform a union operation on the buffers of the objects in the source data and return the result. For region objects, it is required that the objects in the source data do not intersect with each other.

Specifies whether to reserve the fields of the objects in the source dataset. However, For the region dataset, if union the objects and the buffer zone, this parameter is invalid, namely the isUnion is set to true.
member.returns: True if it is removed successfully; false otherwise.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.BufferAnalyst.CreateLineOneSideMultiBuffer(SuperMap.Data.Recordset,SuperMap.Data.DatasetVector,System.Double[],SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.BufferRadiusUnit,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates the one-side multi buffer for a vector line recordset.
member.param: The specified vector recordset that creates buffer area. It only supports line recordset.
The vector dataset to store the result of the buffer analysis. It must be the region dataset.
The specified multi buffer radius list. Its unit is determined by the bufferRadiusUnit parameter.
The specified buffer radius unit.
The specified arc segment count.
Whether to generate a left buffer. Generates the buffer zone on the left side if true, otherwise, generates the right buffer.
Whether to merge all buffers, i.e., whether to perform a union operation on the buffers of the objects in the source data and return the result.

Specifies whether to reserve the fields of the objects in the source dataset. However, For the region dataset, if union the objects and the buffer zone, this parameter is invalid, namely the isUnion is set to true.

Whether to generate a ring buffer. If true, then it will generate a multiple ring buffer zone whose outer buffer zone is adjacent to the inner buffer zone. If false, the outer buffer zone contains the inner buffer zone.
member.returns: True if it is removed successfully; false otherwise.

member.name: T:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.CalculationTerrain
member.summary: The CalculationTerrain class. It is used to calculate aspect, slope, surface area, surface distance, surface volume, profile, cut/fill, find extremes, hill shade, as well as orthographic projection images.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.CalculationTerrain.CalculateSlope(SuperMap.Data.DatasetGrid,SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.SlopeType,System.Double,SuperMap.Data.Datasource,System.String)
member.summary: Calculates slope, and returns the slope grid dataset, i.e., slope map.
member.param: The specified DEM raster to be calculated.
The specified unit type of the slope.

The specified elevation factor (the coefficient for transforming Z values to values with X and Y units in a Grid). For a calculation involving X, Y, and Z values, usually a zFactor needs to be set to make their units consistent. For example, X and Y units are meters, and Z unit is feet. One feet is equal to 0.3048 meter, so the specified zFacor is 0.3048. If you set it as 1.0, then it will not zoom.
Datasource for storing the output datasets.
The specified name of the result dataset.
member.returns: The slope grid dataset.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.CalculationTerrain.CalculateAspect(SuperMap.Data.DatasetGrid,SuperMap.Data.Datasource,System.String)
member.summary: Calculates aspect, and returns the aspect grid dataset, i.e., slope map.
member.param: The specified aspect DEM raster to be calculated.
Datasource for storing the output datasets.
The specified name of the result dataset.
member.returns: The aspect grid dataset.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.CalculationTerrain.CalculateCurvature(SuperMap.Data.DatasetGrid,System.Double,SuperMap.Data.Datasource,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Calculate curvature, and return the average curvature grid dataset.
member.param: The specified DEM grid to be calculated.

The specified elevation factor (the coefficient for transforming Z values to values with X and Y units in a Grid). For a calculation involving X, Y, and Z values, usually a zFactor needs to be set to make their units consistent. For example, X and Y units are meters, and Z unit is feet. One feet is equal to 0.3048 meter, so the specified zFacor is 0.3048. If you set it as 1.0, then it will not zoom.
Datasource for storing the output datasets.
The dataset name of the mean curvature.
The dataset name of the mean profile curvature. The parameter is optional. It is null if you don't need the profile curvature.
The dataset name of the mean plan curvature. The parameter is optional. It is null if you don't need the plan curvature.
member.returns: The raster dataset for the mean curvature.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.CalculationTerrain.ComputeSurfaceDistance(SuperMap.Data.DatasetGrid,SuperMap.Data.GeoLine)
member.summary: Gird surface distance calculation. It is used to calculate curved surface distances along specified line segments or polyline segments on a 3D curved surface simulated by a grid dataset.
member.param: The specified surface distance DEM raster to be calculated.
The specified 2D line for calculating the surface distance.
member.returns: The value of the surface distance. The unit is meter.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.CalculationTerrain.ComputeSurfaceVolume(SuperMap.Data.DatasetGrid,SuperMap.Data.GeoRegion,System.Double)
member.summary: Surface volume calculation. It calculates the volume of the space corresponding to a selected polygon region. The space is between a 3D curved surface simulated by grid dataset and a base plane.
member.param: The specified DEM raster to be calculated the volume.
The specified polygon for volume calculation.
The specified base surface value. It has the same unit with the cell value of the raster dataset to be calculated.
member.returns: The value of the surface volume. Its unit is the square meter multiplied by the value of the raster dataset to be calculated.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.CalculationTerrain.ComputeSurfaceArea(SuperMap.Data.DatasetGrid,SuperMap.Data.GeoRegion)
member.summary: Surface volume calculation. It calculates the volume of the space corresponding to a selected polygon region. The space is between a 3D curved surface simulated by grid dataset and a base plane.
member.param: The specified DEM raster to be calculated the surface area.
The specified polygon for surface area calculation.
member.returns: The value of the surface area. Its unit is meter. Returns -1 indicating the calculation fails.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.CalculationTerrain.CalculateHillShade(SuperMap.Data.DatasetGrid,SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ShadowMode,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,SuperMap.Data.Datasource,System.String)
member.summary: Creates hillshade.
member.param: The specified grid dataset to generate a 3D hillshade.
The render type for the 3D hillshade.

param.name: azimuth
param.para: The specified azimuth of the light source. It is used to determine the direction of the light source, which is the included angle from the the north line of the light source, according to a clockwise direction, to the target direction. The range of the angle is from 0째 to 360째. The north direction is 0째, and it increases in a clockwise direction.

param.name: altitudeAngle
param.para: The specified altitude angle of the light source. It is used to determine the angle of inclination of the light source, which is the included angle between the direction from the light source to the target and the horizontal plane. It ranges from 0-90. If the altitude angle of the light source is 90째, the light source will orthographically illuminate the ground surface.

member.param: The specified elevation factor (the coefficient for transforming Z values to values with X and Y units in a Grid). For a calculation involving X, Y, and Z values, usually a zFactor needs to be set to make their units consistent. For example, X and Y units are meters, and Z unit is feet. One feet is equal to 0.3048 meter, so the specified zFacor is 0.3048. If you set it as 1.0, then it will not zoom.
Datasource for storing the output datasets.
The specified name of the result dataset.
member.returns: Creates the 3D hillshade.

Border matching to on side.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.EdgeMatchMode.TheMidPoint
member.summary:
Border matching on midpoint.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.EdgeMatchMode.TheIntersection
member.summary:
Border matching on intersection.
The border matching connection is the connection and border matching (EdgeMatchLine) in the target dataset and source dataset. The related record endpoint in source dataset and target dataset will be moved to this connection point.

member.name: T:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.Generalization
member.summary: The generalization class provides various functions of cartographic generalization including dissolving the vector data, eliminating the tiny polygons, extracting the center lines from the dual lines, extracting the center line from a region, etc.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.Generalization.Dissolve(SuperMap.Data.DatasetVector,SuperMap.Data.Datasource,System.String,SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.DissolveParameter)
member.summary: Dissolves vector data, and returns the result dataset.
member.param: The specified dataset to be dissolved that must be line dataset or region dataset.
Datasource for storing the output datasets.
The specified name of the result dataset.
The specified dissolving parameter setting.
member.returns: The result vector dataset.
member.exception: The dataset type specified by sourceDataset is not line or region.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.Generalization.Eliminate(SuperMap.Data.DatasetVector,System.Double,System.Double,SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.EliminateMode,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Merges the tiny polygons. The specified tiny polygons that has smaller area will be merged to the adjacent polygon.
member.param: The specified dataset to be merged. Only vector region dataset is support. If you specify other type of dataset, an exception will be thrown.

The specified tolerance of the minimum polygon. It has the same unit with the area calculated by the system (SMAREA field). The polygon, if its area is less than the SMAREA field value, will be eliminated. If the value is greater than 0, the value less than 0 will throw an exception.

The specified vertex tolerance. It has the same unit with the dataset performed the elimination of the tiny polygons. If the distance between two vertex is less than the tolerance, the two vertex can be merged into one vertex automatically. If the value is greater than 0, the value less than 0 will throw an exception.
The specified elimination mode for the tiny polygons. Currently, only EliminateMode.EliminateByArea is supported, that is to say, the tiny polygons are merged to the large polygon nearby.
Specify whether to delete the isolate tiny polygons. Delete them, if true; otherwise, false.
member.returns: True if it is merged successfully; false otherwise.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.Generalization.DualLineToCenterLine(SuperMap.Data.Recordset,System.Double,System.Double,SuperMap.Data.Datasource,System.String)
member.summary: Extracts the center lines from the dual-line recordset according to the specified width.
member.param: The specified dual-line recordset. The recordset type must be line or region.
The specified maximum width of the dual lines. Its value must be greater than 0. It has the same unit with the dual-line recordset.
The specified minimum width of the dual lines. Its value must be greater than or equal to 0. It has the same unit with the dual-line recordset.
Datasource for storing the output center line datasets.
The name of the output center line dataset.
member.returns: The output center line dataset is a line dataset.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.Generalization.RegionToCenterLine(SuperMap.Data.Recordset,SuperMap.Data.Datasource,System.String)
member.summary: Extracts the center line of the region dataset. It is generally used for extracting the center lines of the rivers.
member.param: The specified region recordset whose center line is to be extracted.
Datasource for storing the output datasets.
The specified name of the result dataset.
member.returns: The extracted center line dataset is a 2D line dataset.

member.summary: Extracts the center line of the region object. It is generally used for extracting the center lines of the rivers.
member.param: The specified region object whose center line will be extracted.

member.summary: Auto build regions by topology.
member.param: The referenced region dataset.
Bounds.
Line objects needed when regions are completed.
member.returns: Returns the result object array.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.Generalization.AggregatePoints(SuperMap.Data.DatasetVector,System.Double,SuperMap.Data.Unit,System.Int32,SuperMap.Data.Datasource,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: For clustering the point dataset, use the density cluster arithmetic. Return the cluster type or the polygon.
member.param: The input point dataset.
Density cluster radius.
The unit of density cluster radius.
The range of density cluster point count. It should be larger than or equal to 2. The larger the range is, the cluster condition is more strict. The recommended value is 4.
The datasource of result region dataset. If resultRegionDatasetName parameter is not null, the outDatasource must be valid.

Result region dataset name. If this parameter is valid, it will cluster the point object to region object; if it is null, it will not create the region dataset. This parameter and resultClassFieldName will be valid at least.

pointDataset is used to store result cluster type fields of density clsuetr. If it isn't null, it should be the legal fields in the point dataset. If this parameter is valid, the cluster type will be saved in the field. This parameter and resultRegionDatasetName should be one valid.
member.returns: a boolean, true if successful; Otherwise returns false.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.Generalization.EdgeMatch(SuperMap.Data.DatasetVector,SuperMap.Data.DatasetVector,SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.EdgeMatchParameter)
member.summary: Sheet Join.
member.param: Border matching source dataset. It is only 2D line dataset.
Border matching target dataset. It is only 2D line dataset. It has the same coordinate system with border matching source data.
The border matching parameter class.
member.returns: Whether the border matching is successful.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.Generalization.LineAttachRegion(SuperMap.Data.GeoLine,SuperMap.Data.GeoRegion,System.Collections.Generic.List{SuperMap.Data.GeoRegion},System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Line to region. This interface is primarily used for land data management.
member.param: The line object to be processed.
The rgion object to be processed.
The region object to be compared.

Indicates that while matching line to region, the end pint of line will snap to nodes within the node tolerance. If the tolerance from end point of line to the node is less than toleranceLineAttachRegion, the end point of the line will snap to the node; otherwise, the end point of line will snap to the line segment of region, and will insert foot point on the region. If such nearest foot point does not exist, the line will still snap to region.
Indicates the tolerance for inserting node among regions, and tolerance for finding repeat lines among regions.

It will return false if the maximum distance between the new line and the old line is bigger than specified tolerance. The tolerance value can be less than or be 0, which means that it will not compare the distance between the two lines.
Whether to pre-process the data. It generally is set to be true to ensure the data quality.
member.returns: Return true if processed successfully; false otherwise.

member.name: T:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ComputeType
member.summary: This enumeration defines the constants representing the types of calculation modes in least-cost path grid analyses.

summary.para: Cell path. A path is generated for each grid cell corresponding with the target object.

As shown in the figure below, the red point is the source, and the black-frame polygon is the target. Performing the grid shortest route analysis by this way will get the shortest path denoted by the blue cell in the figure.
Zone path. A path is generated for each grid region corresponding with the target object.

As shown in the figure below, the red point is the source, and the black-frame polygon is the target. Performing the grid shortest route analysis by this way will get the shortest path denoted by the blue cell in the figure.
Single path. Only one path is generated for all grid cells. This path is the one with the least cost among all the paths connecting the entire target area dataset.

As shown in the figure below, the red point is the source, and the black-frame polygon is the target. Performing the grid shortest route analysis by this way will get the shortest path denoted by the blue cell in the figure.

member.name: T:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.DissolveType
member.summary: This enumeration defines the constants representing the dissolving types. Also see DissolveParameter.

summary.para: Group. Groups objects with the same dissolving field values to form a compound object.

In the figure below, an area filled with the same color represents one object. The left figure shows the original region dataset with 3 region objects, A, B, and C. Assume that the Name field values of the objects are all the same. A DissolveType.OnlyMultiPart method with the Name field as the dissolving field results in 1 compound objects (D) as shown in the right figure. This compound object is composed of three sub-objects (D1, D2, and D3).
Dissolve. Merges objects that have the same dissolving field values and are topologically adjacent to form a simple object.

In the figure below, an area filled with the same color represents one object. The left figure shows the original region dataset with 3 region objects, A, B, and C. Assume that the Name field values of the objects are all the same. A DissolveType.Single method with the Name field as the dissolving field results in 2 simple objects (C and D) as shown in the right figure. Only the objects that have the same dissolving field values and are topologically adjacent are merged.

Group after Dissolve. Merges objects that have the same dissolving field values and are topologically adjacent to form a simple object, and then groups objects that have the same dissolving field values but are not topologically adjacent to form a compound object.

In the figure below, an area filled with the same color represents one object. The left figure shows the original region dataset with 3 region objects, A, B, and C. Assume that the Name field values of the objects are all the same. A DissolveType.MultiPart method with the Name field as the dissolving field results in 1 compound object (D) as shown in the right figure. This compound object is composed of 2 sub-objects (D1 and D2).

member.summary: Overlap. If the two events with the same route ID and dissolve field value are overlapped, the two events are merged as one event.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.EventDissolveType.EventConcatenate
member.summary: Concatenate. If the two events with the same route ID and dissolve field value and they concatenates end to end, the two events are merged as one event.

member.name: T:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.EventOverlayType
member.summary: This enumeration defines the constant of the event overlay.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.EventOverlayType.EventIntersect
member.summary: Intersect. The intersection of the two events that have the same route ID is treated as a new event.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.EventOverlayType.EventUnion
member.summary: Union. The event union is complex. First, the intersection is treated as a part of the event. Then, all events (including input and overlap events) are cut by intersection, and the events beyond the intersection are treated as the other part of the event.

member.name: T:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.EventType
member.summary: This enumeration class defines the constants of the event types.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.EventType.LineEvent
member.summary:
Line Event
Line event is on a segment of route. Such as the building year of the road, the traffic state, the pipe diameter, the segment of pipe that leaks. As shown below, in the line event table, every line event (record) has a route ID, FromM and ToM are used to describe the location of the event.
FromM: The measure value of the start point of the event on the route.
ToM: The measure value of the end point of the event on the route.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.EventType.PointEvent
member.summary:
Point Event
Point event is on a accurate location on a route. For instance, the traffic accident on road, the tachymeter on freeway, the valve on pipe, etc. In point event table, every point event (a record) has a corresponding route ID, the location of the event (the measure field) is stored in a field.

member.name: T:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.Exponent
member.summary: This enumeration defines the constants representing the orders of the trend surface equations in Universal Kriging interpolations. The trend existing among the points in a sample point dataset can be simulated with a function or a polynomial.

summary.para: A first-order equation, indicating that a first-order trend exists in the sample point dataset.
A second-order equation, indicating that a second-order trend exists in the sample point dataset.

member.param: The specified dataset to be merged. Only vector region dataset is support. If you specify other type of dataset, an exception will be thrown.

member.name: T:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.GridStatisticsMode
member.summary: This enumeration defines the constants of the raster statistics types.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.GridStatisticsMode.Min
member.summary: Min

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.GridStatisticsMode.Max
member.summary: Max

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.GridStatisticsMode.Mean
member.summary: Mean

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.GridStatisticsMode.Stdev
member.summary: Standard Deviation.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.GridStatisticsMode.Sum
member.summary: Total

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.GridStatisticsMode.Variety
member.summary: Calculates the variety. It represents the number of the unique values in a certain area when conducting neighborhood statistics or zonal statistics.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.GridStatisticsMode.Range
member.summary: Calculates the value domain which is the difference between the minimum value and the maximum value. Currently it only supports zonal statistics.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.GridStatisticsMode.Majority
member.summary: Calculates the majority (i.e., the most frequent cell value). If there are multiple most frequent cell values that occur at the same frequency, then it will take the first value it encounters as the most frequent value.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.GridStatisticsMode.Minority
member.summary: Calculates the minority (i.e., the cell value with the lowest frequency). If there are multiple lowest frequent cell values that occur at the same frequency, then it will take the first value it encounters as the lowest frequent cell value.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.GridStatisticsMode.Median
member.summary: Calculates the median (put the raster values in an ascending order, and then select the value located in the middle). If the number of the cell values is an even number, then it will take the mean of the two middle values.

member.name: T:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.InterpolationAlgorithmType
member.summary: This enumeration defines the constants representing the types of interpolation methods.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.InterpolationAlgorithmType.IDW
member.summary:
Inverse Distance Weighted (IDW) method.
IDW is using the mean value of the neighboring discrete points to estimate each grid value to generate the grid dataset. It affects the estimate value most when the point is closer to the center of the discrete area. IDW is a simple method, and the speed of this method is a little faster.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.InterpolationAlgorithmType.SimpleKriging
member.summary:
Simple Kriging method.
Simple Kriging is a commonly-used Kriging interpolation method. It assumes that the expected value (mean) of the field values for interpolation is a known constant.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.InterpolationAlgorithmType.Kriging
member.summary:
Ordinary Kriging method.
This method generates the grid dataset by simulating the grid value according to some given points and a certain math functions. It not only can generate a surface, but also can calculate the accuracy of the estimated result. So, this method has a higher precision.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.InterpolationAlgorithmType.UniversalKriging
member.summary:
Universal Kriging method.
Universal Kriging is also a commonly-used Kriging method. For this method, it is assumed that the expected value (mean) of the field values for interpolation is an unknown variable. Universal Kriging is suitable if there is a certain trend existing in the sample data and this trend can be fit with a function or a polynomial.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.InterpolationAlgorithmType.RBF
member.summary:
Radial Basis Function (RBF) method.
This method supposes the variety is smooth, and it has two characteristics: 1. The surface should cross the given points.2. The surface should have the minimum curvature.This method has advantage in creating curve and contour which have higher vision request.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.InterpolationAlgorithmType.DENSITY
member.summary: Dot density interpolation.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.InterpolationAlgorithmType.BarrierKriging
member.summary:
Barrier Kriging method.
The method allows setting a barrier dataset, the area which locates will be ignored in the analysis.

member.name: P:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.InterpolationParameter.SearchRadius
member.summary: Gets or sets the search radius. Its unit is same with the point dataset or the record dataset for the interpolation. The search radius limits the search range of the points involved in the calculation. When calculating an unknown value of some location, all the sample points within the circular range whose center is the location and radius is the value set by this attribute will be involved in the calculation (i.e., the predicted value of this location is determined by the sample points within this range).
member.value: The default value is 0.0. The maximum search radius is 1.2 times larger than the diagonal of the rectangle within the extent of the point dataset.

The dissolve field collection. Only the events with the same attribute value can be dissolved. It supports all the field types (FieldType) besides except the binary (LongBinary).
The dissolve type.
The datasource for storing the result event table. If null, the result event table is output to the input datasource.

member.summary: Overlap event table. Overlap two event tables and output one event table, representing union and intersection.
member.param: The input event parameter.
The overlap event parameter.
The overlapping event type.
The datasource for storing the result event table. If null, the result event table is output to the input datasource.
The specified name of the result dataset.
The result overlap event parameter.
The specified tolerance used to determine whether the created line event is a zero-length event. It has same unit with the value of the output event table.

It is used to specify whether to keep the attribute field. If true, it will write all the attribute fields except the system fields of the input event table and the overlay event table into the output event table. The field name ends with "_in" is from the input event table, and its name ends with "_over " is from the overlay event table. If false, it will not to write any field into the output event table.
Whether to keep the zero-length line event. If true, the zero-length event will be written to the result event table; otherwise, false.
member.returns: The overlapping output dataset. Returns null if it fails.

member.name: T:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.NeighbourShapeType
member.summary: The enumeration defines the constants for the neighbor shapes.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.NeighbourShapeType.Rectangle
member.summary:
Rectangle neighborhood.
The size of the rectangle neighbor is determined by its width and height, and all cells placed in the rectangle participate in this operation. The default values for width and height are 0 (in geographic units or grid units).

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.NeighbourShapeType.Circle
member.summary:
Circle neighborhood.
The size of the circle neighborhood is determined by the specified radius. All cells placed in or overlapping the circle participate in this operation. The default radius is 0 (in geographic units or grid units).

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.NeighbourShapeType.Annulus
member.summary:
Annulus neighborhood.
The size of the annulus neighbor is determined by both inner radius and outer radius. All cells placed in the annulus participate in this operation. The default both inner radius and outer radius are 0 (in geographic units or grid units).

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.NeighbourShapeType.Wedge
member.summary:
Wedge neighborhood.
The size of the wedge neighborhood is determined by radius, start angle, and end angle. All cells placed in the wedge participate in this operation. The default radius is 0 (in geographic units or grid units), and the default values of start angle and end angle are 0.

member.name: T:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.NeighbourUnitType
member.summary: The enumeration defines the unit type constant for neighborhood analysis.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.NeighbourUnitType.Cell
member.summary: Raster coordinates, i.e., using the raster data as the neighborhood unit.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.NeighbourUnitType.Map
member.summary: Geographic coordinates, i.e., using the map unit as the neighborhood unit.

summary.para: The OverlayAnalyst class is used to perform various types of overlay analyses on two input datasets or recordsets. Common overlay analyses include Clip, Erase, Union, Intersect, Identity, Symmetrical difference, Update, etc.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.OverlayAnalyst.Clip(SuperMap.Data.DatasetVector,SuperMap.Data.DatasetVector,SuperMap.Data.DatasetVector,SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.OverlayAnalystParameter)
member.summary: Clips a vector dataset with another dataset which can be region. The method will clip and remove parts of the first dataset outside the ones of second dataset.
member.param: the identifier of the dataset to be clipped (the first dataset). The type of this dataset can be any of the following: point, line, or region.
the identifier of the dataset that is used to clip (the second dataset). The type of this dataset must be region.
The result vector dataset.
The parameter of overlay analysis, which is used to set fields to be kept in output. The settings of OverlayAnalystParameter object will be invalid in CLIP operation.
member.returns: True if it is removed successfully; false otherwise.

member.summary: Clips a recordset with another recordset which can be region. The method will clip and remove parts of the first recordset outside the ones of second recordset.
member.param: The first recordset to be clipped.
The second recordset used to clip the first recordset.
The vector dataset stored output.
The parameter of overlay analysis, which is used to set fields to be kept in output. The settings of OverlayAnalystParameter object will be invalid in CLIP operation.
member.returns: True if it is removed successfully; false otherwise.

member.summary: Erases a dataset with a region dataset. The method will erase and remove the part of the first dataset inside the second dataset, and the output dataset will keep all the fields of the first dataset, the others will be updated after erasing.

The second dataset used to erase the first dataset.
The vector dataset stored output.
The parameter of overlay analysis, which is used to set fields to be kept in output.
member.returns: True if it is removed successfully; false otherwise.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.OverlayAnalyst.Erase(SuperMap.Data.Recordset,SuperMap.Data.Recordset,SuperMap.Data.DatasetVector,SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.OverlayAnalystParameter)
member.summary: This is a type of overlay analysis involving erasing objects in a recordset. The process is to clip and delete the first recordsets object parts that are contained in the second recordset. The geographical coordinate systems of the erasing recordset, the recordset to be erased, and the result dataset must be the same.
member.param: The first recordset to be erased, which must be point, line and region type.
The second recordset used to erase the first recordset, which only is the region type.
The vector dataset stored output.
The parameter of overlay analysis, which is used to set fields to be kept in output.
member.returns: True if it is removed successfully; false otherwise.

member.summary: Computes an intersection operation on the first dataset and second dataset and uses the intersection to perform the union operation on the first dataset.
member.param: The first dataset to be identity.
The second dataset used to erase the first dataset.
The vector dataset stored output.
The parameter of overlay analysis, which is used to set fields to be kept in output.
member.returns: True if it is removed successfully; false otherwise.

member.summary: This is a type of overlay analysis involving determining identity of objects in a recordset. In the process, all the operated recordset's objects as well as the objects resulted from intersecting the operated recordset with the operating recordset are reserved in the result dataset. The geographical coordinate systems of the operating recordset, the operated recordset, and the result dataset in an Identity analysis must be the same.
member.param: The first recordset to be identity, which can be point, line, or region.
The second recordset used to erase the first recordset, which must be region.
The vector dataset stored output.
The parameter of overlay analysis, which is used to set fields to be kept in output.
member.returns: True if it is removed successfully; false otherwise.

member.summary: Performs an intersection analysis to the input dataset. Removes the portions of the input dataset outside the intersected dataset and the intersected portions will be split and kept in output.
member.param: The input dataset to be intersected, which must be point, line and region type.
The intersected dataset used to intersect the first dataset, which only is the region type.
The vector dataset stored output.
The parameter of overlay analysis, which is used to set fields to be kept in output.
member.returns: True if it is removed successfully; false otherwise.

member.summary: This is a type of overlay analysis involving intersecting objects on recordsets. In the process, the intersected recordsets object parts that are not contained in the intersecting dataset are clipped and deleted. The geographical coordinate systems of the intersecting recordset, the intersected recordset, and the result dataset must be the same.

The intersected recordset used to intersect the first recordset, which only is the region type.
The vector dataset stored output.
The parameter of overlay analysis, which is used to set fields to be kept in output.
member.returns: True if it is removed successfully; false otherwise.

The dataset used to perform union analysis. It can be region dataset.

member.summary: Performs an update analysis on two region datasets. The update analysis is the process that the second dataset replace the area they overlap in the first dataset, namely, performed a erasing and pasting operations.

member.name: T:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ResampleMode
member.summary: This enumeration defines the constants representing the types of grid reclassification algorithms.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ResampleMode.Nearest
member.summary:
Nearest Neighbor.
The nearest neighbor technique assigns the value of the cell whose center is closest to the center of the output cell. It is the resampling technique of choice for discrete, or categorical, raster data, such as land-use rasters, because it does not change the value of the input cells.
In the image above, the black line represents the input raster, the green fill represents the output raster, and the red point represents the center for a certain output cell. The value of the grid is recalculated. The value of the cell nearest to this point (in purple) is taken part in the neighborhood analysis.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ResampleMode.Bilinear
member.summary:
Bilinear interpolation
Bilinear interpolation uses the value of the four nearest input cell centers to determine the value on the output raster. The new value for the output cell is a weighted average of these four values, adjusted to account for their distance from the center of the output cell. Since the values for the output cells are weighted based on distance, and then averaged, the bilinear interpolation is best used for data where the location from a known point or phenomenon determines the value assigned to the cell. For example, elevation, slope, magnitude of earthquake from the epicenter.
In the image above, the black line represents the input raster, the green fill represents the output raster, and the red point represents the center for a certain output cell. The value of the grid is recalculated. The 4 values of the cells nearest to this point (in purple) is taken part in the bilinear interpolation analysis.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ResampleMode.Cubic
member.summary:
Cubic convolution
Cubic convolution is a resampling technique similar to bilinear interpolation except that the weighted average is calculated from the values of the 16 nearest input cell centers. Compared with bilinear interpolation, cubic convolution has a tendency to sharpen the edges of the input data since more cells are involved in the calculation of the output value. This method also changes the original cell values, and even exceeds the range of the input raster. The cubic convolution is suit for resampling aviation or RS images.
In the image above, the black line represents the input raster, the blue fill represents the output raster, and the red point represents the center for a certain output cell. The value of the grid is recalculated. The 16 values of the cells nearest to this point (in purple) is taken part in the IDW.

member.name: T:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.GenerateType
member.summary: This enumeration defines the generate type for route dataset.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.GenerateType.ByPoint
member.summary:
By point.
Two types of data: line data and reference point data. The process to generate the routing: firstly, the reference point is matched with the line data by Route Identifier Field; secondly, the scale value of the line vertex is obtained from the scale value of the reference point; finally, the route dataset will be generated. The scale value of the reference point is stored in an attribute field.
There are generally 3 types of the position situations between the reference point and its corresponding line vertex. As shown in the figure below, the blue line is line data used for generating the routing, the red square point is an reference point, the light-orange circular area is a range decided by the tolerance. The tolerance is used to decide whether the reference point is effective, which can be specified by users. It is different from the vertex tolerance of the dataset.
If the reference point coincides with the vertex or is within the specified tolerance (see: reference point 1 in the figure), then the scale value of the reference point will be assigned to the vertex directly. If there are more than one reference points within the tolerance (see: vertex 4), then it will take the M value of the nearest reference point.
If the reference point is beyond the range of the vertex tolerance, the system will judge whether it is "On the Line". If the vertical distance between the reference point and its corresponding arc is less than the tolerance, then it is "On the Line" and the M value of the reference point can be used to calculate the M value of the vertex. If it is greater than the tolerance, then the reference point will be treated as "Not on the Line" and it will not participate in calculating the M value of the tolerance. For example, the vertex 2 in the figure is not within the range of the tolerance, but it is "On the Line" according to the rule, then the value of the vertex 2 can be got from the interpolation of the M values of reference point 1 and 2. The reference 3 is not either within the range of the tolerance or "On the Line", so it is an invalid reference point and will not participate in calculating the M value of vertex 3. Hence, the M value of vertex 3 will be got from the interpolation of the reference point 2 and 4.
If there are no reference points around the line object for calculating (i.e., within the tolerance of the vertex, it neither have reference points nor have these points that can be treated as "On the Line"), then this line object will not generate its routing. Hence, it may be different between the object number of the route dataset generated by this way and the object number of the original line dataset.
It may be different between the object number of the route dataset generated by this way and the object number of the original line dataset.
Note: The M values of the reference points corresponding to the same line object that are arranged in a certain direction should be incremented, decremented or remain constant.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.GenerateType.BySingleField
member.summary:
By single field.
This method is to generate the route dataset according to an attribute field of the line data. This field records a scale value which will be the end-M value (i.e., the M value of the last vertex on a route). The start-M value (i.e., the M value of the first vertex) is 0. If there is an intermediate vertex, then its M value will be got by interpolation.
The object number of the original line dataset is consistent with the object number of the route dataset generated by this way.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.GenerateType.ByDoubleFields
member.summary:
By double field.
This method is to generate the route dataset according to two attribute fields of the line data. The scale values of the two fields will be treated as the start-M value and end-M value of the corresponding routes respectively, and the M value of the intermediate vertex is also calculated by the interpolation.
The object number of the original line dataset is consistent with the object number of the route dataset generated by this way.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.GenerateType.ByLength
member.summary:
By double fields.
This method is to use the distance along the line from the vertex of the line object to its start vertex as the scale value of each vertex so as to generate the route dataset. Obviously, the start-M value of each route is 0 in the result route dataset, and the end-M value is the length of the corresponding line. The unit of the scale value of the result route is meter.
The object number of the original line dataset is consistent with the object number of the route dataset generated by this way.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.SearchMode.QuadTree
member.summary:

Note: This mode only applies to kriging and RBF interpolation.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.SearchMode.KdTreeFixedRadius
member.summary:
The KdTreeFixedRadius mode. All the sample points within the specified radius are taken part in the cell interpolation operation.
This method is to determine the sample points by the search radius (SearchRadius) and the expected minimum sample points (ExpectedCount).
That is to say, the value of this certain point is determined by the points located in your setting radius.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.SearchMode.KdTreeFixedCount
member.summary:
The KdTreeFixedCount mode. The number of sample points you set are participated in the interpolation analysis.
This method is to determine the sample points by the search radius (SearchRadius) and the expected maximum sample points (ExpectedCount).
That is to say, the value of this certain point is determined by those N points.

member.name: T:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.SmoothMethod
member.summary: Used to smooth the boundary when the isoline or isoregion from grid or DEM data is generated.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.SmoothMethod.BSpline
member.summary:
The B-spline method.
In the computer science subfields of computer-aided design and computer graphics, the term B-spline frequently refers to a spline curve parametrized by spline functions that are expressed as linear combinations of B-splines (in the mathematical sense above). A B-spline is simply a generalisation of a B챕zier curve, and it can avoid the Runge phenomenon without increasing the degree of the B-spline.
After using the B-spline method for the non-closed line object, the relative position of its two endpoints remains the same.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.SmoothMethod.Polish
member.summary:
The polish method.
The polish method is a relatively simple calculation, smooth way faster processing speed, but the effect is relatively limited. Its main process is the folding line of the two adjacent segments, respectively, at a distance of the angle vertex third segment length is added at the node, and the newly added on both sides of the angle between the two nodes connected to the original line segment node polished.
A close smooth line can be got by repeatedly polishing its angle. After using the polish method for the non-closed line object, the relative position of its two endpoints remains the same.

member.name: F:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.SmoothMethod.None
member.summary: Do not smooth the data.

member.name: T:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.VariogramMode
member.summary: Defines the semivariogram mode of Kriging Interpolation method. Such as Exponential Variogram Mode, Gaussian Variogram Mode and Spherical Variogram Mode.The selected mode influences the prediction of the unknown values, particularly when the shape of the curve nears the origin differs significantly. The steeper the curve near the origin, the more influence the closest neighbors will have on the prediction. As a result, the output surface will be less smooth. Each model is designed to fit different types of phenomenon more accurately.

summary.para: Exponential Variogram Mode.

Exponential Variogram ModeThis mode is applied when spatial autocorrelation decreases exponentially with increasing distance. Here the autocorrelation disappears completely only at an infinite distance. The exponential model is also a commonly used model. The choice of which model to use is based on the spatial autocorrelation of the data and on prior knowledge of the phenomenon.
Exponential Variogram Mode is commonly used.
Gaussian Variogram Mode.
Spherical Variogram Mode.

Spherical Variogram Mode. This mode shows a progressive decrease of spatial autocorrelation (equivalently, an increase of semivariance) until some distance, beyond which autocorrelation is zero. The spherical model is one of the most commonly used models.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.VisibilityAnalyst.CalculateViewShed(SuperMap.Data.DatasetGrid,SuperMap.Data.Point3D,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,SuperMap.Data.Datasource,System.String)
member.summary: The one-point viewshed analysis is to analyze the visible range of a viewpoint.
member.param: The specified grid surface dataset for the viewshed analysis.
The specified viewpoint

The specified start point. The unit is degree. The north direction is 0 degree, and the observation direction rotates clockwise. If the specified value is negative or greater than 360째, then it will be converted automatically in range [0, 360째].

The specified view angle, Its unit is degree, and the maximum value is 360째. The view angle is in range [start angle, start angle+view angle]. For example, if the start angle is 90째 and the view angle is 180째, then the view range is in [0, 180째]. Note: if the specified view angle is 0 or negative, then no matter how many degrees the start angle is, the range of the view angle is [0, 360째].
The specified observation radius. It restricts the size of the view extent. A radius less than or equal to 0 indicates that no limitation is applied. The unit is in meters.
The specified datasource for saving the viewshed analysis result.
The specified name of the dataset for saving the viewshed analysis result.
member.returns: The target dataset of the one-point viewshed analysis.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.VisibilityAnalyst.CalculateViewShed(SuperMap.Data.DatasetGrid,SuperMap.Data.Point3Ds,System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[],SuperMap.Data.Datasource,System.String,SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ViewShedType)
member.summary: The multi-points viewshed analysis is to analyze the visible regions of the multiple points, which can be the public visible regions or non-public visible regions.
member.param: The specified grid surface dataset for the viewshed analysis.
The specified viewpoints.

The specified start angles which have one-to-one correspondence with the viewpoint. The unit is degree. The north direction is 0 degree, and the observation direction rotates clockwise. If the specified value is negative or greater than 360째, then it will be converted automatically in range [0, 360째].

The specified view angles which have one-to-one correspondence with the view point and the start angle. Its unit is degree, and the maximum value is 360째. The view angle is in range [start angle, start angle+view angle]. For example, if the start angle is 90째 and the view angle is 180째, then the view range is in [0, 180째]. Note: if the specified view angle is 0 or negative, then no matter how many degrees the start angle is, the range of the view angle is [0, 360째].
The specified observation radius collection. It restricts the size of the view extent. A radius less than or equal to 0 indicates that no limitation is applied. The unit is in meters.
Datasource for storing the output datasets.
The specified name of the result dataset.
The specified viewshed type. It can be the intersection or the union of the viewsheds of the observation points.
member.returns: The target dataset of the multi-points viewshed analysis.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.VisibilityAnalyst.RadarShieldAngle(SuperMap.Data.DatasetGrid,SuperMap.Data.Point3D,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,SuperMap.Data.Datasource,System.String )
member.summary: According to the topographic map and the radar center point, the point data set of the largest radar shielding angle on each side is returned. The azimuth is the angle from the true north direction, and one radar shadow point is returned every 1 degree clockwise.
member.param: Delete the data set or DEM. Image data sets are not supported.
3D point object, which represents the coordinates of the radar center point and the height of the radar center.
The starting angle of the radar azimuth, in degrees, is 0 degrees in the north direction and rotates clockwise. The range is 0 to 360 degrees.

Specified azimuth angle in degrees and a maximum of 360 degrees. The observation angle is based on the starting angle, that is, the viewing angle range is [starting angle, starting angle + viewing angle].
The scope of observation, in meters. If set to less than 0, it represents the entire terrain map range.
Target data source. If you pass in null, the default is the data source where the terrain data is located.
Result data set name.
member.returns: returns the 3D point dataset, where Z represents the terrain height at the location of the point. The data set records the point where the radar shadow angle is the largest in each azimuth, and adds the fields "ShieldAngle", "ShieldPosition" and "RadarDistance" to record the radar shadow angle, the angle between the point and the north direction, and the point and point. The distance from the radar center.

member.summary: The VisibleResult class. This class provides the result of a visibility analysis on observation points and target points. It also provides information about barrier points if the target points are not visible to the observation point(s).

member.name: P:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.VisibleResult.Visible
member.summary: Gets whether the target point(s) are visible to the observation point(s).

member.name: P:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.VisibleResult.FromPointIndex
member.summary: Gets the index of an observation point. If the visibility analysis is on only two points, the index of the observation point is 0.

member.name: P:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.VisibleResult.ToPointIndex
member.summary: Gets the index of a target point. If the visibility analysis is on only two points, the index of the target point is 0.

member.name: P:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.VisibleResult.BarrierPoint
member.summary: Gets the coordinates of a barrier point. If the observation points and the target points are not visible to each other, then the attribute value is the first barrier point between the two points. If the two points are visible to each other, the default values are assigned to the barrier point coordinates.

member.name: P:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.VisibleResult.BarrierAlterHeight
member.summary: Gets the suggested maximum altered height of barrier points. If you modify the cell value (elevation) of the grid surface which has the barrier point so as to make it less than or equal to this maximum value, then this point will no longer obstruct the view, but it may have the other barrier points. The cell value can be modified by the SetValue method of the DatasetGrid class.

member.name: T:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ZonalStatisticsAnalystParameter
member.summary: The ZonalStatisticsAnalystParameter class. This class provides parameter settings for zonal statistics.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ZonalStatisticsAnalystParameter.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs a new ZonalStatisticAnalystParameter object.

member.name: M:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ZonalStatisticsAnalystParameter.#ctor(SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ZonalStatisticsAnalystParameter)
member.summary: Constructs a new object identical to the given ZonalStatisticAnalystParameter object.
member.param: The given ZonalStatisticAnalystParameter object.

member.name: P:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ZonalStatisticsAnalystParameter.StatisticsMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the type of the zonal statistics.

member.name: P:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ZonalStatisticsAnalystParameter.IsIgnoreNoValue
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to ignore no value or not. If true, any cell with no value will not be calculated; If false, any cell with no value will still be output as a cell without value.

member.name: P:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ZonalStatisticsAnalystParameter.TargetDatasetName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the result dataset.

member.name: P:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ZonalStatisticsAnalystParameter.TargetDatasource
member.summary: Gets or sets the datasource for storing the output data.

member.name: P:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ZonalStatisticsAnalystParameter.TargetTableName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the result attribute table.

member.name: P:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ZonalStatisticsAnalystParameter.PixelFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the pixel format. It has been abolished. See ZonalStatisticsOnRasterValue for the introduction of the pixel type of the result raster.

member.name: P:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ZonalStatisticsAnalystParameter.ValueDataset
member.summary: Gets or sets the value raster to be statistics. Currently, only raster data is supported.

member.name: P:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ZonalStatisticsAnalystParameter.ZonalDataset
member.summary: Gets or sets the zonal dataset for the statistics. It only supports the raster dataset or vector region dataset whose PixelFormat is UBit1, UBit4, UBit8 and UBit16.
member.exception: The specified pixel format of the raster dataset is not UBit1, UBit4, UBit8 or UBit16; or the specified vector dataset is not region dataset.

member.name: P:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ZonalStatisticsAnalystParameter.ZonalFieldName
member.summary: Gets or sets the field used to identify the zone in the vector zoning data. The field type only supports the int32.

member.name: T:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ZonalStatisticsAnalystResult
member.summary: The ZonalStatisticsAnalystResult class. This class offers the zonal statistics results, including raster dataset and attribute tables.

member.summary: The Constructor.

member.summary: Gets the zonal statistics raster datasets.

member.name: P:SuperMap.Analyst.SpatialAnalyst.ZonalStatisticsAnalystResult.ResultTable
